conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity curve on a v-t graph.
Object B's velocity curve starts at the origin, decreases initially until time t1, reaches its minimum value at t1, then increases until t2, and appears concave upward throughout the interval.
From 0 to t1, the slope of curve B is negative and becoming less steep, indicating a negative acceleration that is becoming less negative.
From t1 to t2, the slope of curve B changes from negative to positive at t1 and continues to increase, indicating a positive acceleration that is increasing in magnitude.
Considering the entire interval from 0 to t2, the acceleration starts as negative, continuously increases, passes through zero at t1, becomes positive, and continues to increase until t2.
The trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2 is continuously increasing, starting as negative, passing through zero at t1, and becoming positive and increasing.
